text.headline: US Westward Expansion <small>Mean center of United States population</small>
text.text:
The mean center of U.S. population is determined by the United States Census Bureau from the results of each census. Defined as the point at which an imaginary, flat, weightless, and rigid map of the United States would balance perfectly if weights of identical value were placed on it so that each weight represented the location of one person on the date of the census.

This is an overview or title slide to show all the points in your story routed on your map.

A look at the US during this first Census data collection.

Map (left) is an example of a URL to an image hosted on the web.

text.headline: 1800: Thomas Jefferson
text.text:
In 1800, Thomas Jefferson was elected as the President of the United States, not too far from Howard County Maryland the new center of US population. He of course did not have a Twitter account, but this is fun.

You can embed a tweet into your StoryMapJS using the URL to the tweet.

text.headline: 1810: Loudoun County, Virginia
text.text:
The population moved 40 miles northwest of Washington, DC. The US also acquired new territory west of the original 13 states in 1803 through the Louisiana Purchase from France.

The headline and location name to the previous and next slide (left and right), show up under the navigation arrows.

text.headline: 1820: Census image from Flickr
text.text:
The mean population has moved into what is now West Virginia.

This example of an 1820 Census record pulled from Flickr gives an example of how the Census was conducted by hand.

text.headline: 1830: Old state lines of Virginia
text.text: A cool map showing how West Virginia was once part of Virginia. It is the only state to form by seceding from a Confederate state, it did so in 1863 and was almost named the State of Kanawha.

text.headline: 1840: Annexation of Texas
text.text:
The mean population has moved into Upshur County, Virginia (now W. Virginia). By the mid 1840s the US was fighting the Mexican American War with one of the results being the annexation of Texas.

You can add a YouTube URL like this Crash Course on the Mexican American War.

media.caption: Crash Course on the Mexican American War

text.headline: 1850: Uncle Tom's Cabin
text.text:
The mean is in Wirt County in what is now West Virginia. In 1852, Harriet Beecher Stowe's 'Uncle Tom's Cabin' was published, galvanizing the abolitionist movement.

Embed a YouTube URL like this one about Uncle Tom's Cabin.

text.headline: 1860: Abraham Lincoln
text.text:
Abraham Lincoln is elected as the 16th President of the U.S.

This excerpt is embedded from Wikipedia

.

text.headline: 1870: Finally counting everyone
text.text: This census was the first to record the names and other personal information of all African-Americans, including those who were formerly enslaved. In researching your African-American ancestors, moving backward from the present, the 1870 federal census may be the last census in which you are able to identify these ancestors by name. The 1870 census often even serves as a powerful tool in identifying former slave owners, a necessary step for anyone desiring to reclaim the heritage of their enslaved ancestors.

text.headline: 1880: Decade when film is created
text.text:
The mean is in Boone County, Kentucky, 8 miles west by south of Cincinnati, OH. Here are some frames from film pioneer Louis Le Prince's record of Leeds Bridge and horse traffic made as a series of glass plates in 1889 (some sources say paper). The first film ever made.

Embed videos from YouTube.

media.caption: Frames Louis Le Prince's record of Leeds Bridge

text.headline: 1890: Columbus, IN Plane Crash
text.text:
Mean population is now 20 miles east of Columbus, IN. On July 25, 2013, a plane crashed into a house in Columbus.

Using a Storify URL you can embed the sequence of events.

media.caption: Minute-by-minute coverage of the Columbus, Indiana, plane crash

text.headline: 1900: Hear some music from the time
text.text:
The mean population is now 6 miles southeast of Columbus. Listen to 'In the sweet bye and bye' by Harry MacDonough. Original recording by Roger Harding released in 1898. Popular music from 1900-1910.

Embed soundclips from Soundcloud.

media.caption: In the sweet bye and bye

text.headline: 1910: Old Photos
text.text: The mean is now in the city of Bloomington. Which had the University of Indiana since 1820. In 1910 the population was 8,838 people. One hundred years later in 2010 the population was 80,405 people.

text.headline: 1920: An American in the Making
text.text:
An old film from the time showing Gary, Indiana, which is near Owen County where the population mean is in 1920. Director/Photographer: Carl Lewis Gregory, Locations: Ellis Island in New York Harbor; the Gary, Indiana works of the United States Steel Corporation.

Embed a Vimeo.

text.headline: 1930: Dorothy as a kid
text.text:
Greene County, Indiana located 3 miles northeast of Linton. Judy Garland singing 'Bubbles' from 1930.

Embed from Daily Motion.

text.headline: 1940: World at war
text.text: The mean population has moved to Sullivan County, Indiana, 2 miles southeast by east of Carlisle. Here is a newspaper from 1941, Chicago Tribune publisher Col. Robert McCormick had been opposed to the U.S. getting into a war with Japan, but once war was declared, the Tribune lines up solidly behind FDR's war efforts.

text.headline: 1950: Video about the railroads
text.text: Richland County, Illinois is the new mean center of the US. Here is an educational documentary from the time by the 31 members of the Illinois Association of Railroads. It examines the problems facing railroads in the 1950's such as competition from cars, trucks and planes, as well as the unfair tax burden faced by railroads at the time.

text.headline: 1960: Chicago Blues
text.text:
Clinton County, Illinois has become the new mean of the populatin as it moves west. This is the time period of Chicago Blues and Chess Records released the Best of Muddy Waters which included this song.

Embed a Soundcloud track

text.headline: 1970: To the Moon!
text.text: St. Clair County, Illinois is the new population center. In 1969, the US not only went west, but landed on the moon! Check out this cool Vimeo of the Apollo 11 trip in 100 seconds.

text.headline: 1980: Westward ho!
text.text: Jefferson County, Missouri a 1/4 mile west of DeSoto. This is the first year that the mean was outside and west of the territory of the original 13 states.

text.headline: 1990: Hubble
text.text:
The US mean moved west to Crawford County, Missouri, but the US again makes a leap into space, launching the Hubble telescope.

YouTube video featuring images taken by Hubble space telescope.

text.headline: 2000: A new millenium
text.text:
Phelps County, Missouri is the new center of US population. Here's a good laugh and some good perspective, remember Y2K?

YouTube video

text.headline: 2010: And Twitter happened
text.text:
The new center is Texas County, Missouri, which has nothing to do with Texas. In the past decade many things happened but a big one is the founding of Twitter in 2006. Here is the #1 most retweeted tweet from 2010.

Another example of an embedded tweet.
